Kenaikan Iuran BPJS Kesehatan 100 Persen Berdampak pada Pasien Gagal Ginjal
04 Nov 2019, 11:36 by iman


Kenaikan Iuran BPJS Kesehatan 100 Persen Berdampak pada Pasien Gagal Ginjal

KBRN, Jakarta : Komunitas Pasien Cuci Darah Indonesia (KPCDI) mengritik keputusan Presiden Joko Widodo (Jokowi) yang menaikkan iuran Badan Penyelenggara Jaminan Sosial (BPJS) Kesehatan sebesar 100 persen pada Kamis (24/10/2019). 
Ketua umum KPCDI, Tony Samosir menilai kenaikan iuran BPJS Kesehatan telah membebani masyarakat kelas bawah yang justru memiliki daya beli rendah. Apalagi, besaran kenaikannya hampir mendekati asuransi komersial. 
"Sangat memberatkan khususnya kelompok masyarakat yang tergolong Fakir Miskin dan Orang Tidak Mampu tapi belum terdaftar sebagai peserta JKN PBI," tegas Tony di Jakarta, Senin (4/11/2019). 
Menurut Tony, sebagai besar pasien dengan penyakit kronis seperti gagal ginjal sudah kehilangan pekerjaan karena dianggap tidak produktif. 
"Bahkan bekerja pun sudah terbatas karena terikat jadwal cuci darah dan kondisi kesehatan lainnya," ujarnya.
Menurut Tony  pasien seperti ini tidak lagi memiliki penghasilan, bahkan jika berpenghasilan pun nilainya sangat rendah. Mereka ini masih menjadi peserta BPJS di kelas mandiri. Selain itu,  bila kenaikan iuran menjadi 100 persen, maka akan memberatkan pengeluran mereka. Ia mencontohkan, bila dalam satu keluarga ada 4 orang, dengan iuran baru mencapai angka 160 ribuan untuk kelas 3 (tiga), belum lagi kelas 1 (satu). 
"Angka Itu seperti kita membayar pajak mobil kelas premium dan sangat tidak masuk akal. Ini akan terjadi gelombang tunggakan pembayaran iuran BPJS Kesehatan ke depan," jelasnya.
Tony mengatakan para pasien yang tergabung di KPCDI saat ini sedang berupaya untuk turun kelas 3 dan mencoba keberuntungannya dengan mendaftar menjadi peserta PBI.
“Tak ada cara lain, kami harus turun kelas biar hidup bisa berkelanjutan, walau sulit mendaftar ke Jaminan PBI. Hidup bukan hanya untuk membayar BPJS, tapi ada keperluan dasar lainnya yang harus dipenuhi," katanya.
Menurut Tony, harusnya Pemerintah memperbaiki akar masalah dari BPJS Kesehatan, seperti bagaimana cara menagih tagihan bagi peserta yang menunggak iuran, perbaikan menajemen klaim bahkan mengevaluasi sistem rujukan yang justru dinilai merugikan. 
"Karena kenaikan iuran bukan solusi mengatasi defisit BPJS Kesehatan. Justru hanya membebani masyarakat. Khususnya pasien cuci darah yang biaya pengobatannya tak sepenuhnya dijamin oleh BPJS," ucap pasien cuci darah yang sudah transplantasi ginjal ini
Melihat kondisi keuangan BPJS Kesehatan yang terus terpuruk, menurut Tony harusnya Negara yang paling banyak menganggung porsi untuk menutup defisit. 
"UUD Tahun 1945 menyatakan tegas akan konsep Sistem Jaminan Sosial, antitesa dari sistem kesehatan yang komersial,"sebutnya. 
Ia menilai tugas menyelenggarakan satu Sistem Jaminan Sosial ada pada Negara. Alasannya TAP MPR RI No. X/MPR/2001 yang menugaskan kepada presiden RI untuk membentuk Sistem Jaminan Sosial Nasional.
"Salah satu asas gotong royong dalam BPJS Kesehatan mau dihilangkan oleh Pemerintah. Harusnya yang mampu Negara, dia yang paling banyak menanggung porsi keuangan BPJS Kesehatan. Bukan rakyat yang harus menanggung beban itu," kecamnya.
Untuk itu, pemerintah Presiden Jokowi harus mendengar usulan Komisi IX DPR RI dan masyarakat luas yang menolak besaran kenaikan iuran BPJS Kesehatan.

Increase in Health BPJS Contributions 100 Percent Impacts on Kidney Failure
Nov 04 2019, 11:36 by iman


Increase in Health BPJS Contributions 100 Percent Impacts on Kidney Failure

KBRN, Jakarta: The Indonesian Community for Dialysis Patients (KPCDI) criticized the decision of President Joko Widodo (Jokowi) to increase the contribution of the Health Insurance Administering Body (BPJS) by 100 percent on Thursday (10/24/2019).
KPCDI Chairperson Tony Samosir assessed that the increase in BPJS Health contributions had burdened lower class people who actually had low purchasing power. Moreover, the magnitude of the increase is almost close to commercial insurance.
"It is very burdensome especially for the community groups that are classified as Poor and Needy People but have not been registered as JKN PBI participants," said Tony in Jakarta, Monday (11/04/2019).
According to Tony, most patients with chronic diseases such as kidney failure have lost their jobs because they are considered unproductive.
"Even work is already limited because it is bound by dialysis schedules and other health conditions," he said.
According to Tony, these patients no longer have income, even if the income is very low. They are still BPJS participants in independent classes. In addition, if the contribution increase becomes 100 percent, it will burden their expenses. He gave an example, if in one family there were 4 people, with new contributions reaching 160 thousand for class 3 (three), not to mention class 1 (one).
"That figure is like we are paying a premium class car tax and is very unreasonable. This will be a wave of arrears in payment of BPJS Health contributions going forward," he explained.
Tony said the patients who are members of KPCDI are currently trying to get off grade 3 and try their luck by registering to become PBI participants.
"There is no other way, we have to go down a class so that life can be sustainable, even though it is difficult to register with PBI Guarantee. Life is not just to pay BPJS, but there are other basic needs that must be met, "he said.
According to Tony, the Government should fix the root problems of BPJS Health, such as how to collect bills for participants in arrears, improve claims management and even evaluate the referral system which is considered detrimental.
"Because the increase in fees is not a solution to overcome the BPJS Health deficit. Instead it only burdens the community. Especially dialysis patients whose medical expenses are not fully guaranteed by BPJS," said the dialysis patient who had a kidney transplant
Looking at BPJS Health's financial condition which continues to plummet, according to Tony, the State should be the most responsible for covering the deficit.
"The 1945 Constitution firmly states the concept of the Social Security System, the antithesis of the commercial health system," he said.
He considered the task of organizing a Social Security System in the State. The reason is TAP MPR RI No. X / MPR / 2001 which assigned the president of Indonesia to form a National Social Security System.
"One of the principles of mutual cooperation in the Health BPJS wants to be eliminated by the Government. It should be able to the State, he who bears the most financial portion of BPJS Health. It is not the people who have to bear the burden," he denounced.
For this reason, President Jokowi's government must listen to the proposals of the House of Representatives Commission IX and the wider community who reject the amount of BPJS Health contributions.
